facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 265 of 1964 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated August 7, 1962 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 312 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 265 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 7, 1962 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 312 of 57.

facts.text: The temple of Sri Kodandaramaswami is located in the village of Varagali, district of Nellore.

anchor.surface_text: In the village of Varagali, in the district of Nellore, there is a temple in which is enshrined the idol of Sri Kodandaramaswami.

facts.text: The temple was built in the middle of the last century by Burla Rangareddi who managed the temple and its properties during his lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: The temple was built in the middle of the last century by one Burla Rangareddi who managed the affairs of the temple and its properties during his life- time.

facts.text: After Burla Rangareddi's death, his son Venkata Subbareddi managed the temple.

anchor.surface_text: After his death his son, Venkata Subbareddi is in management.

facts.text: By a deed dated August 19, 1898, Venkata Subbareddi relinquished his interest in the properties to Vemareddi Rangareddi, whose family are defendants 1 to 5.

anchor.surface_text: By a deed dated August 19 1898 Venkata Subbareddi relinquished his interest in the properties in favour of one Vemareddi Rangareddi whose family members are defendants 1 to 5.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed a petition before the Assistant Commissioner for Hindu Religious Endowments, Nellore, alleging mismanagement by the first defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff filed a petition before the Assistant Commissioner , for Hindu Religious Endowments, Nellore, alleging mismanagement of the temple and its properties by the first defendant.

facts.text: First defendant contested the application, alleging properties belonged to his family, not the temple.

anchor.surface_text: Notice was issued to the 1st defendant to show cause why the temple properties ghould number be leased out in public auction and the first, defendant companytested the application alleging that the properties were number the properties of the temple but they belonged to his family.

facts.text: Assistant Commissioner submitted report to Hindu Religious Endowments Board, Madras, recommending a scheme of management.

anchor.surface_text: After enquiry, the Assistant Commissioner submitted a report to the Hindu Religious Endowments Board, Madras, recommending that a scheme of Management may be framed for the administration of the. temple and its properties.

facts.text: Hindu Religious Endowments Board by order dated October 5, 1949 held that the temple was a public temple.

anchor.surface_text: The Board held an enquiry and by its order dated October S. 1949 held that the temple was a public one.

facts.text: On January 18, 1950, 1st defendant filed O.P. No. 3 of 1950 before District Judge Nellore to set aside Board's order, declare temple private, and properties personal.

anchor.surface_text: On January 18, 1950 the 1 st defendant filed O.P. number 3 of 1950 on the file of the District Judge Nellore  1  for setting aside the order of the Board dated October 5, 1949 declaring the temple of Sri Kodandaramaswamiwari as a temple defined in s. 6, cl. 17 of the Act,  2  for a declaration that the temple was a private temple and  3  for a declaration that the properties set out in the schedule annexed to the petition were the personal properties of his family and they did number companystitute the temple properties.

facts.text: Plaintiff got impleaded as 2nd respondent in O.P. No. 3/1950.

anchor.surface_text: Originally, the Commissioner. Hindu Religious Endowment Board, Madras was impleaded as the sole respondent in the petition. The present plaintiff later on got himself impleaded as the 2nd respondent therein.

facts.text: Respondents contested O.P., claiming temple public and properties temple's.

anchor.surface_text: Both the respondent companytested the petition on the ground that the temple was a public temple and that the properties mentioned in the schedule were the properties of the temple and number the personal properties of the 1st defendant.

facts.text: District Judge Nellore passed compromise decree on October 28, 1954 declaring temple public, petitioners 1-4 hereditary trustees, Schedule A properties personal subject to annual charge of 12-1/2 putties paddy and Rs. 600.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge, Nellore recorded the companypromise and passed a decree in terms thereof by his order dated October 28, 1954, The material clauses of the companypromise decree, Ex. B-11 are as follows.- That Sri kodandaramaswami temple, Varagali, be and hereby is declared as a temple as defined in section 6. clause 17 of the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act That petitioners 1 to 4 be and hereby are, declared as the present hereditary trustees of the said temple. That the properties set out in schedule A filed herewith be and hereby are, declared as the person proper. ties of- the family of the petitioners subject to a charge as slow below That petitioners 1 to 4 their heirs, successors administrators and assignees do pay to the said temple for its maintenance 12-1/2 putties of good Mologolukulu paddy 6001- every year by the 31st of March ...

facts.text: Present suit instituted on October 31, 1955 for declaration that provision in compromise decree declaring Schedule lands personal properties not valid or binding on temple.

anchor.surface_text: The Present suit was instituted on October 3 1. 1955 for a declaration that the provision in the companypromisedecree that the lands mentioned in the schedule were the personal properties of defendants 1 to 5 and number the absolute properties of the temple, was number valid. and binding on the temple.

facts.text: Trial court dismissed the suit on grounds of defect and bar under s.93 HRCE Act 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt dismissed the suit on the ground that the suit was defective and that s. 93 of. the Hindu Religious and, Charitable Endowments Act of 1951 was a bar to the institution of the suit.

facts.text: Plaintiff appealed to AP High Court as A.S. 312 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Against the decree of the trial companyrt the plaintiff preferred an appeal--A S, 312 of 1957 to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: AP High Court on August 7, 1962 allowed amendment of plaint, held no bar under s.93, remanded suit.

anchor.surface_text: The. plaintiff also filed M.P. number6422 of 1962 praying for amendment of the plaint the effect that the companypromise decree in O. P. number 3 of 1950 was number valid and binding on the temple. After hearing defendants 1 to.5 the High Court allowed the amendment sought for by the plaintiff and-held that the amendment cured the defect with regard to the prayer for a declaration to have the companypromise decree set aside partially. The High Court further held that s. 93 of the Hindu. Religious and Charitable Endowments Act was number a bar to the suit ... In the result, the High Court owed the appeal and remanded the suit to the trial companyrt for disposing the same on the remaining issues.

facts.text: Supreme Court held compromise decree invalid as Commissioner did not represent the deity.

anchor.surface_text: In-, the present case numbersuch action was taken by the District Court in O. P. number 3 of 1950 and as there was numberrepresentation of the deity in that judicial proceeding it is manifest that the companypromise decree cannot be binding upon the deity.

facts.text: Supreme Court held compromise decree beyond scope of O.P. No. 3/1950 under s.84(2) Madras Act II 1927.

anchor.surface_text: The proceeding was brought under s. 84 2  of the old Act  Act II of 1927  for setting aside the order of the Board dated October 5, 1949 declaring the temple of Sri Kodandaramaswami as a temple ... Such a declaration was outside the purview of s. 84 2  of Madras Act 11 of 1927 and companyld number have been granted.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted declaratory decree that compromise decree in O.P. 3/1950 not valid or binding on temple.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the companytention of respondent number is companyrect and that he is entitled to a declaratory decree that the companypromise decree in O.P. number 3 of 1950 was number valid and was number binding upon Sri Kodandaramaswami temple. ... For the reasons expressed, we hold that the decree passed by the trial companyrt should be set aside and the plaintiff- respondent number I should be granted a declaratory decree that the companypromise decree in O.P. number 3 of 1950 on the file of the District Court Nellore is number valid and binding on Sri Kodandaramaswami temple.

facts.text: Compromise between petitioners 1-5 and Commissioner (1st respondent) in O.P. 3/1950.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, there was a companypromise between the petitioners 1 to 5 on the one, hand and the Commissioner, the 1st respondent on the other.

facts.text: Madras Act II of 1927 repealed, Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act 1951 enacted, State of Andhra Pradesh formed.

anchor.surface_text: For reasons which are number apparent on the record the petition was number disposed of for a number of years. In the meantime Madras Act II of 1927 was repealed and the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act of 1951 was enacted. Then came the formation of the State of Andhra Pradesh.

arguments.claim: The suit is barred by s.42 of the Specific Relief Act as plaintiff is a mere worshipper without legal character or right to property

anchor.surface_text: It was argued for the appellants that the plaintiff has brought the suit as a mere worshiper of the temple and that he has no legal or equitable right to the properties of the temple which constitute the subject-matter of the suit. It was pointed out that the plaintiff has no asked for a declaration of his legal character as a worshiper of the temple but he has asked for the setting aside of the compromise decree in O. P. No. 3 of 1950 with regard to the nature of the temple properties.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: barred by the provisions of s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act. Upon this argument we think that there is both principle and authority for holding that

arguments.court_reasoning: Suit provides substantial relief declaring compromise invalid, falls outside s.42 purview, governed by CPC s.9/O7R7; worshipper entitled as cestui que trust

arguments.claim: Declaratory suits governed exclusively by s.42 Specific Relief Act; requirements not fulfilled

anchor.surface_text: It was contended, in the first place, on behalf of the appellants that declaratory suits are governed exclusively by S. 42 of the Specific Relief Act and if the requirements of that section are no fulfilled no relief can be granted in a suit for a mere declaration.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: barred by the provisions of s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act. Upon this argument we think that there is both principle and authority for holding that

arguments.court_reasoning: s.42 not exhaustive; historical development shows courts have inherent power for substantial declarations

arguments.court_reasoning: Compromise invalid; temple public, properties temple's

holdings.text: the suit of the plaintiff for a declaration that the compromise decree is not binding on the deity is maintainable as falling outside the purview of s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act.

anchor.surface_text: A declaration of this kind was the subject matter of appeal in Fischer v. Secretary of State for India in Council 1  and falls outside the purview of s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act and will be governed by the general provisions of the Civil Procedure Code like S. 9 or 0. 7, r. 7. On behalf of the respondents reliance was placed on the decision of the Judicial Committee in Sheoparsan Singh v. Ramnandan Prasad Singh 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.42 Specific Relief Act not exhaustive of declaratory powers; historical evolution from Chancery Act shows courts' inherent power for substantial relief declaring acts void; precedents like Fischer (declaration act void not within s.42), Pratab Singh (partial invalidity declarable); Sheoparsan distinguished as will affirmed appropriately; worshipper as cestui que trust entitled.

holdings.text: the worshipper of a Hindu temple is entitled, in certain circumstances, to bring a suit for declaration that the alienation of the temple properties by the de jure Shebait is invalid and not binding upon the temple.

anchor.surface_text: the worshipper of a Hindu temple is entitled, in certain circumstances, to bring a suit for declaration that the alienation of the temple properties by the de jure Shebait is invalid and not binding upon the temple. if a Shebait has improperly alienated trust property a suit can be brought by any person interested for a declaration that such alienation is not binding upon the deity

holdings.reasoning_summary: Worshippers positioned as cestui que trustent; can seek declaration invalidity of improper alienation without possession right; supported by precedents like Vidhyapurna, Kalyana Venkataramana, Abdur Rahim.

holdings.text: the compromise decree cannot be binding upon the deity.

anchor.surface_text: In-, the present case no such action was taken by the District Court in O. P. no 3 of 1950 and as there was no representation of the deity in that judicial proceeding it is manifest that the compromise decree cannot be binding upon the deity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No representation of deity in O.P. 3/1950 as no next friend appointed by court; only shebait represents deity; Commissioner has superintendence under s.20 HRCE but no authority to represent in judicial proceedings; precedent Pramath Nath requires disinterested next friend when shebait adverse.

holdings.text: As a matter of law the only person who can represent the deity or who can bring a suit on behalf of the deity is the Shebait.

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of law the only person who can represent the deity or who can bring a suit on behalf of the deity is the Shebait, and although a deity is a juridical person capable of holding property, it is only in an ideal sense that property is so held.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deity juridical person holds property ideally; shebait has possession/management/sue rights; Commissioner lacks authority despite s.20 control.

holdings.text: the compromise decree was beyond the scope of the proceedings in O.P. No. 3 of 1950 and was, therefore, invalid.

anchor.surface_text: It was also contended by Mr. P. Rama Reddy on behalf of respondent No. I that the compromise decree was beyond the, scope of the proceedings in O.P. number 3 of 1950 and was, therefore, in. valid. ... Such a declaration was outside the purview of s. 84 2  of Madras Act 11 of 1927 and could not have been granted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: O.P. under s.84(2) Madras Act II 1927 only to set aside Board's order declaring public temple; declaration properties personal and charge creation outside scope even after amendment post-1951 Act.

holdings.text: the plaintiff- respondent No. I should be granted a declaratory decree that the compromise decree in O.P. No. 3 of 1950 on the file of the District Court Nellore is not valid and binding on Sri Kodandaramaswami temple.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the contention of respondent No. I is correct and that he is entitled to a declaratory decree that the compromise decree in O.P. No. 3 of 1950 was not valid and was not binding upon Sri Kodandaramaswami temple. ... For the reasons expressed, we hold that the decree passed by the trial court should be set aside and the plaintiff- respondent No. I should be granted a declaratory decree

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combining invalidity due to lack of deity representation and beyond scope; suit maintainable; merits decided as parties requested, no remand needed.

precedents.citation: Fischer v. Secretary of State for India in Council

anchor.surface_text: Fischer v. Secretary of State for India in Council,  1  Lord Macnaghten said of this section Now, in the first place it is at least open to doubt whether the present suit is within the purview of s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act.

precedents.case_name: Fischer v. Secretary of State for India in Council
precedents.cited_proposition: Suit to declare true construction of a statute and to pronounce an act done in contravention void is not within purview of s. 42 Specific Relief Act
precedents.cited_holding: it is at least open to doubt whether the present suit is within the purview of s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act. ... That is not the sort of declaratory decree which the framers of the Act had in their mind.

precedents.cited_proposition: S. 42 Specific Relief Act does not apply to suit for declaration that compromise decree obtained by fraud when minors unrepresented is not binding
precedents.cited_holding: S. 42 of the Specific Relief Act did not apply to the case and ... gave to the appellant a decree setting aside the decree complained of

anchor.surface_text: A declaration of this kind was the subject matter of appeal in Fischer v. Secretary of State for India in Council 1  and falls outside the purview of s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act and will be governed by the general provisions of the Civil Procedure Code like S. 9 or 0. 7, r. 7. On behalf of the respondents reliance was placed on the decision of the Judicial Committee in Sheoparsan Singh v. Ramnandan Prasad Singh 1 .

On behalf of the respondents reliance was placed on the decision of the Judicial Committee in Sheoparsan Singh v. Ramnandan Prasad Singh 1 .

the worshipper of a Hindu temple is entitled, in certain circumstances, to bring a suit for declaration that the alienation of the temple properties by the de jure Shebait is invalid and not binding upon the temple. if a Shebait has improperly alienated trust property a suit can be brought by any person interested for a declaration that such alienation is not binding upon the deity

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of law the only person who can represent the deity or who can bring a suit on behalf of the deity is the Shebait, and although a deity is a juridical person capable of holding property, it is only in an ideal sense that property is so held.

As a matter of law the only person who can represent the deity or who can bring a suit on behalf of the deity is the Shebait, and although a deity is a juridical person capable of holding property, it is only in an ideal sense that property is so held.

anchor.surface_text: It was also contended by Mr. P. Rama Reddy on behalf of respondent No. I that the compromise decree was beyond the, scope of the proceedings in O.P. number 3 of 1950 and was, therefore, in. valid. ... Such a declaration was outside the purview of s. 84 2  of Madras Act 11 of 1927 and could not have been granted.

It was also contended by Mr. P. Rama Reddy on behalf of respondent No. I that the compromise decree was beyond the, scope of the proceedings in O.P. number 3 of 1950 and was, therefore, in. valid. ... Such a declaration was outside the purview of s. 84 2  of Madras Act 11 of 1927 and could not have been granted.

We are, therefore, of the opinion that the contention of respondent No. I is correct and that he is entitled to a declaratory decree that the compromise decree in O.P. No. 3 of 1950 was not valid and was not binding upon Sri Kodandaramaswami temple. ... For the reasons expressed, we hold that the decree passed by the trial court should be set aside and the plaintiff- respondent No. I should be granted a declaratory decree
